If the Commission has approved a licensed manufacturer or contractor to provide preinspected and preshuffled decks or batches of decks, a facility operator may use preinspected and preshuffled decks or batches of decks obtained from that licensed manufacturer or contractor in the same manner as decks or batches of decks that are preinspected and preshuffled §R of this regulation.
Card Rotation. The facility operator shall change:
The decks of cards used for all banked table games except the games set forth in §T(2)—(5) of this regulation at least every:
4 hours, if the cards are dealt by hand; and
8 hours, if the cards are dealt from a manual or automated dealing shoe;
The decks of cards used in blackjack at least every:
4 hours, if the cards are dealt by hand; and
24 hours, if the cards are dealt from a manual or automated dealing shoe;
The decks of cards used in mini baccarat at least every 24 hours, if the cards are dealt from a manual or automated dealing shoe;
The decks of cards used in midi baccarat after the play of each dealing shoe; and
The two decks of cards used in poker at least every 24 hours.

section.heading: Dealing Shoes and Automated Card Shuffling Devices.

para.text: In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Base plate” means an interior shelf of a dealing shoe on which a card rests.
“Face plate” means the front wall of the dealing shoe against which the next card to be dealt rests and which typically contains a cutout.
A manual dealing shoe must be designed and constructed to maintain the integrity of the game at which the shoe is used, and shall include these features:
At least the first 4 inches of the base plate shall be white;
The sides of the shoe below the base plate shall:
Be transparent, have a transparent sealed cutout, or be otherwise constructed to prevent any object from being placed into or removed from the portion of the dealing shoe below the base plate; and
Permit the inspection of this portion of the shoe; and
A stop underneath the top of the face plate that precludes the next card to be dealt from being moved upwards more than 1/8 inch.
In addition to the requirements of §C of this regulation, a manual dealing shoe used in minibaccarat, midibaccarat or baccarat must also meet these specifications:
Have a removable lid that is opaque from the point where it meets the face plate to a point at least 4 inches from the face plate;
The sides and back above the base plate must be opaque; and
Have a device within the shoe which, when engaged, prevents the cards from moving backward in the shoe.
An automated card shuffling device that has been submitted, and approved by the Commission may be used in addition to a manual or automated dealing shoe.
An automated shuffling device must meet a 95 percent confidence level using a standard chi-squared test for goodness of fit.
An automated card shuffling device may not provide any information that can be used to aid a player in:
Projecting the outcome of a game;
Tracking the cards played and cards remaining to be played;
Analyzing the probability of the occurrence of an event relating to a game; or
Analyzing the strategy for playing or betting to be used in a game.
Tampering.

At the beginning of each gaming day and before a card is placed in them, the floorperson assigned to the table shall inspect the dealing shoes and automated card shuffling devices to be used for gaming to ensure that they have not been tampered with.
Evidence of tampering shall be immediately reported to a Commission compliance representative in a written report that shall include:
The date and time when the tampering was discovered;
The name and signature of the individual who discovered the tampering;
A description of the evidence of tampering;
The table number where the dealing shoe or shuffler was used; and
The name and signature of the person assigned to directly operate and conduct the game and the supervisor assigned the responsibility for supervising the operation and conduct of the game.
Pai gow shall be played with a set of 32 rectangular tiles
Each tile in a set must be identical in size and shading to every other tile in the set, and shall:
Be made of a nontransparent black material, formed in the shape of a rectangle, and be not smaller than 2-1/2 inches in length, 1 inch in width and 3/8 inch in thickness;
Have the surface of each of its sides perfectly flat, except that the front side of each tile must contain spots which extend into the tile exactly the same distance as every other spot;
Have on the back or front of each tile an identifying feature unique to each facility operator;
Except for the front side containing spots, have an identical texture and finish on each side;

Have no tile within a set contain any markings, symbols or designs that would enable a player to know the identity of any element on the front side of the tile or that would distinguish any tile from any other tile within a set; and
Have identifying spots on the front side of the tiles which are red, white or both.

Unless a facility has submitted to the Commission under COMAR 36.05.03.16 a detailed schematic depicting the actual size and identifying features on pai gow tiles, and the Commission has approved the submission, pai gow tiles shall not be used in a facility
Each set of tiles shall be packaged separately and sealed under COMAR 36.05.03.19.

section.heading: Pai Gow Tiles — Receipt, Storage, Inspection, and Removal.

para.text: Receipt.

A shipment of tiles that a facility operator receives from a manufacturer or contractor shall be unloaded immediately and transported to a secure area which is covered by the facility operator’s surveillance system under the supervision of at least two employees of the facility operator.
The boxes of tiles shall then be inspected by at least two employees of the facility operator to ensure that the seals on each box are intact, unbroken, and free from tampering.

Boxes that do not appear to be intact, unbroken and free from tampering shall be inspected immediately to ensure that the tiles in those boxes conform to the requirements of this chapter and there is no evidence of tampering with them.

If tiles inspected as required under §A(2)(a) of this regulation show no evidence of tampering, they shall be placed, along with boxes of tiles that are intact, unbroken and free from tampering, for storage in a storage area, the location and physical characteristics of which shall be approved by the Commission under COMAR 36.05.03.16.
The functions required under §A(1) and (2) of this regulation shall be performed by at least the following employees of a facility operator:
A floorperson or above; and
An employee from the security department.
Sets of tiles which are to be distributed to gaming pits or tables for use in gaming shall be distributed from the approved storage area.
Approved Storage Area. The approved storage area shall have two separate locks, to which access shall be controlled as follows:
The security department shall maintain one key and the gaming operations department shall maintain the other key; and
An employee of the gaming operations department below a floorperson in the facility’s organizational hierarchy may not have access to the gaming operations department key.

Once each gaming day and at other times as may be necessary, a floorperson or above, in the presence of a security department employee, shall remove the appropriate number of sets of tiles from the approved storage area.
Envelopes and containers used to hold or transport tiles shall be:
Transparent;
Designed or constructed with seals so that any tampering is evident; and
Submitted to, and approved by, the Commission in advance under COMAR 36.05.03.16.
Distribution of Tiles.
The floorperson or above shall distribute sufficient sets of tiles to the pit manager or above in each pai gow pit.
The pit manager or above shall then distribute the sets of tiles to the dealer at each pai gow table and place extra sets of tiles in the reserve in the pit stand.
Sets of tiles in the reserve shall be placed in a locked compartment in the pit stand, keys to which shall be in the possession of the pit manager or above.
Damaged Tiles.

If during the course of play a damaged tile is detected, the dealer or a floorperson shall immediately notify the pit manager or above, who shall bring a substitute set of tiles to the table from the reserve in the pit stand to replace the entire set of tiles.

A set containing a damaged tile shall be placed in an envelope or container, identified by table number, date and time the tiles were placed in the envelope or container and sealed and signed by the dealer and the floorperson responsible for supervising the table or the pit manager or above.
The pit manager or above shall maintain the sealed envelope or container in a secure place within the pit until collection by a security department employee.
Collection.
The floorperson responsible for supervising the table or the pit manager or above shall collect used tiles which shall be placed in an envelope or container when removed from active use.

A label shall be attached to each envelope or container which identifies the table number, date and time the tiles were placed in the envelope or container and sealed and signed by the dealer and the floorperson responsible for supervising the table or the pit manager or above.
The pit manager or above shall maintain the sealed envelopes or containers in a secure place within the pit until collection by a security department employee.
Removal.

A facility operator shall remove a tile from play if there is any indication of tampering, flaws, or other defects that might affect the integrity or fairness of the game, or at the request of a Commission compliance representative or other Commission employee.

A label shall be attached to each envelope or container which identifies the table number, date, and time the tiles were placed in the envelope or container and sealed and signed by the dealer and the floorperson responsible for supervising the table or the pit manager or above.
The pit manager or above shall maintain the sealed envelopes or containers in a secure place within the pit until collection by a security department employee.

Extra sets of tiles in the reserve which have been opened shall be placed in an envelope or container with a label attached to each envelope or container which identifies the date and time the tiles were placed in the envelope or container and sealed and is signed by the pit manager or above.

At the end of each gaming day or in the alternative, at least once each gaming day, as designated by the facility operator and approved by the Commission under COMAR 36.05.03.16, and at other times as may be necessary:

A security department employee shall collect and sign all envelopes or containers with damaged tiles, tiles used during the gaming day, and all extra tiles in the reserve which have been opened, and return the envelopes or containers to the security department; and

A floorperson or above may collect all extra sets of tiles in the reserve which have not been opened, and, if collected, all unopened sets of tiles shall be cancelled, destroyed, or returned to the approved storage area.
Inspection.

When envelopes or containers of used tiles and reserve sets of tiles which have been opened are returned to the security department, the security department shall inspect the tiles for tampering, marks, alterations, missing, or additional tiles or anything that might indicate unfair play.
The procedures for inspecting sets of tiles shall include:
Sorting of tiles by pairs;
Visually inspecting the sides and back of each tile for tampering, markings, or alterations; and
Inspecting the sides and back of each tile with an ultraviolet light.

The individual performing the inspection shall complete a work order form which details the procedures performed, lists the tables from which the tiles were removed and the results of the inspection, and shall sign the form upon completion of the inspection procedures.
The facility operator shall submit to the Commission the training procedures for the employees performing the inspections required under this subsection in its internal controls.

Evidence of tampering, marks, alterations, missing, or additional tiles or anything that might indicate unfair play discovered during the inspection, or at any other time, shall be immediately reported to a Commission compliance representative by the completion and delivery of a two-part Tile Discrepancy Report.
The two-part report shall include the tiles which are the subject of the report.
A Commission compliance representative shall retain the tile for further inspection.
The Commission compliance representative receiving the tile shall sign the original and duplicate copy of the tile discrepancy report and retain the original.
The facility operator shall retain the duplicate copy.

If after completing the inspection procedures required under §N of this regulation, it is determined that a complete set of 32 tiles removed from a gaming table is free from tampering, markings, or alterations, the set shall be packaged separately and sealed before being returned to the pai gow storage area for subsequent use.
A facility operator shall develop internal control procedures for returning the repackaged tiles to the tile inventory in accordance with §P of this regulation.
Individual tiles from different sets may not be used to make a complete set for subsequent gaming.
A facility operator may create replacement and reconstructed sets in accordance with the following requirements:

If after completing the inspection procedures required under §M of this regulation, it is determined that a tile has scratches or other markings on the back, sides or edges which make the tiles unsuitable for continued use, the tile shall be removed from the set and destroyed in accordance with §R of this regulation.
The remaining usable tiles from the set shall be designated as a replacement set.
The employee who removes the tiles from a set shall complete a two-part form that shall:
Include the date and time the tiles were removed from the set;
Identify the specific tile or tiles removed from the set and sent for destruction; and
Contain the name and signature of the individuals involved.
The duplicate copy of the form shall be retained with the replacement set and the security department shall retain the original.

The assistant table games shift manager or above shall return the replacement set, accompanied by the duplicate copy of the form, to the tile inventory under §P of this regulation where replacement sets shall be inventoried and stored separately from any stored and new, used or complete reconstructed sets.
Tiles in one or more replacement sets may be used to create a complete reconstructed set of tiles in accordance with the following procedures:

The assistant table games shift manager or above shall conduct an inspection of each reconstructed set in the storage area, in the presence of a security department employee, and ensure that any replacement tile possesses the same color, texture, and finish as all other tiles in the reconstructed set.

The assistant table games shift manager or above shall sort the tiles by pairs and verify the needed replacement tile or tiles and visually inspect the sides, backs and edges of each tile in the reconstructed set for tampering, markings, and alterations and for comparison as to shading, texture and finish.

After a complete set of tiles has been assembled from replacement sets, the assistant table games shift manager or above shall attach a label to the envelope or container for the reconstructed set, which shall:
Include the date and time of reconstruction;
Contain the signature of the assistant table games shift manager or above and the security department employee who witnessed the inspection; and
Identify the inspection steps that were followed to determine that the reconstructed set of tiles is suitable for use in gaming.

A facility operator shall submit to the Commission for approval internal control procedures for returning the reconstructed sets into inventory, identifying all reconstructed sets and maintaining an accurate inventory balance of remaining replacement sets.
A facility operator shall submit internal control procedures for:
An inventory system which includes records of at least the following:
The balance of sets of tiles on hand;
The sets of tiles removed from storage;
The sets of tiles returned to storage or received from a manufacturer or contractor;
The date of each transaction; and
The signatures of the individuals involved;
A daily reconciliation of the:
Sets of tiles distributed;
Sets of tiles destroyed or cancelled;
Sets of tiles returned to the approved storage area; and
Sets of tiles in the tile reserve in a pit stand; and
A physical inventory of the sets of tiles at least once every 3 months.
An inventory shall be performed by an individual with no incompatible functions and shall be verified to the balance of the sets of tiles on hand required in §Q(1)(a) of this regulation.
Discrepancies shall immediately be reported to a Commission compliance representative.
Destruction or Cancellation.
Destruction or cancellation of tiles other than those retained for Commission inspection shall be completed within 7 days of collection.
The method of destruction or cancellation shall be included in the facility operator’s internal controls.
The destruction or cancellation of tiles shall take place in a secure location in the licensed facility covered by the facility operator’s surveillance system.
Tile Rotation. A facility operator shall change the tiles at least every 12 hours.

section.heading: Dealer Controlled Electronic Table Games — Requirements.

para.text: Wagering. A facility operator may conduct electronic wagering at a table game in accordance with this chapter.
Electronic wagering at a table game shall be conducted through the use of a dealer controlled electronic table game system.
If a dealer controlled electronic table game system is in use at a table game, a player may make only those wagers that are approved by the Commission.

The computer controlling the dealer controlled electronic table game system shall be under dual key control, with one key controlled by the accounting department and the other key controlled by the table games department or the slot operations department.

All aspects of a dealer controlled electronic table game system, including the computer and any related hardware, software or related devices, shall be tested by an independent certified testing laboratory and approved by the Commission prior to use by a facility operator.
In addition to the requirements for table games under COMAR 36.05, a facility operator using a dealer controlled electronic table game system shall include in its internal controls, at a minimum:
Procedures to ensure the physical security of the computer and related hardware, software and other devices.
Procedures to ensure the integrity and security of all sensitive data and software.
Procedures to ensure that access to sensitive data and software is limited to only appropriate personnel.
Procedures to ensure the logging of the events and the availability of records to enable an effective audit of the conduct of the system and the reporting of revenue.
A dealer controlled electronic table game shall have the ability to authenticate the transmission of data between the various components of the dealer controlled electronic table game system.
A dealer controlled electronic table game system shall:
Credit funds to the game account of a player when a player buys in to a game at a particular table game and debit any remaining funds from the game account when a player cashes out of the game;
Permit a player to:
Wager from a game account;
Collect a losing wager from a game account; and
Pay a winning wager by crediting the amount of the winnings and corresponding wager to the game account;
In the game of Poker:
Debit a game account and increment pot for a wager;
Distribute a winning pot by crediting the game account of a winning player in the appropriate amounts;
Extract the rake from a player or pot according to the rake procedures established under the standard rules for Poker, and debit the game account of a player in the correct amounts; and
Make a player’s balance or table stakes visible to all players in the game;
Depict the transactions described in §F(1), (2) and (3) of this regulation through one or more electronic fund displays that are visible to each player and to the dealer or boxperson;
Disclose to a player at all times the current balance in the player’s game account;
Accurately report and audit the table game’s win or loss, or Poker revenue, in accordance with the standard rules for Poker;
Be capable of generating reports setting forth, by gaming day, for each table game using the dealer controlled electronic table game system:
The total amount deposited into the game account of a player;
The total amount deposited into game accounts by all players;
The total amount credited to the game account of a player in payment of winnings;
The total amount credited to the game accounts of all players in payment of winnings;
The total amount collected from a player as losing wagers;
The total amount collected from all players as losing wagers;
The total amount withdrawn from game accounts by each player;
The total amount withdrawn from game accounts by all players; and
The table game win or loss; and
If applicable, for Poker:
The total amount deducted from the game account of a player for collection of Poker rake time charges under the standard rules for Poker;
The total amount collected from the accounts of each player for collection of Poker rake time charges under the standard rules for Poker;
The total amount collected from Poker pots for collection of Poker rake under the standard rules for Poker; and
The table game Poker revenue.

The display of a virtual chip on a dealer controlled electronic table game that depicts the transactions described in §F(1), (2) and (3) of this regulation is not required to meet the physical requirements for chips under COMAR 36.05.02.
A dealer controlled electronic table game system shall have no more than 14 table game positions in operation for every dealer.
After installation, Agency staff shall inspect a dealer controlled electronic table game system prior to use by a facility operator.

section.heading: Dealer Controlled Electronic Table Game System — Procedures.

para.text: If a table game using a dealer controlled electronic table game system is equipped with a bill validator, a player may participate in wagering at the table game by:
Inserting currency or a gaming voucher into the bill validator; or
Presenting currency or value chips to the dealer or boxperson.
A dealer controlled electronic table game system that is equipped with a bill validator shall communicate with the Commission’s central monitor and control computer system to:
Transmit accounting and auditing information;
Retrieve information in real time; and
Activate or disable a dealer controlled electronic game.

If a table game using a dealer controlled electronic table game system is not equipped with a bill validator, a player shall participate in wagering by presenting currency or value chips to the dealer or boxperson.
When a player presents currency, a gaming voucher, or value chips as described in §A or C of this regulation:
The dealer controlled electronic table game system shall:
Credit to the player’s game account an amount of funds equivalent to the currency, gaming voucher or value chips presented by the player; and
Display on the electronic fund display the amount of funds deposited into the player’s game account; and
The player shall acknowledge the amount of funds deposited into the player’s game account.
A player shall cash out of a table game using a dealer controlled electronic table game system by receiving:
A gaming voucher equal in value to the balance in the player’s game account; or
Value chips from the dealer or boxperson from the table inventory container that are equal in value to the balance in the player’s game account.
After a player has cashed out of a table game using a dealer controlled electronic table game system, the dealer or boxperson shall zero out the electronic fund display of the player’s game account.
A facility operator shall submit to the Commission for approval the layout for a table game that contains at least:
The name or logo of the facility operator;
Betting areas designated for the placement of wagers authorized under the standard rules; and

Inscriptions that advise a player of the payout odds or amounts for all permissible wagers offered by the facility operator, except that if payout odds or amounts are not inscribed on the layout, a sign identifying the payout odds or amounts for all permissible wagers shall be posted at each table.
If a facility operator offers a Progressive Payout Wager, a table shall have a progressive table game system for the placement of Progressive Payout Wagers that includes a:
Wagering device at each betting position that acknowledges or accepts the placement of the Progressive Payout Wager; and

Device that controls or monitors the placement of Progressive Payout Wagers at the gaming table and includes a lock-out button or other mechanism that prevents the recognition of any Progressive Payout Wager that a player attempts to place after the dealer has announced “no more bets”.
A table shall have a drop box and a tip box attached on the same side of the gaming table as, but on opposite sides of, the dealer, as approved by the Commission.

The Commission may approve an alternative location for the tip box when a card shuffling device or other table game equipment prevents the placement of the drop box and tip box on the same side of the gaming table as, but on opposite sides of, the dealer.
Each table shall have a discard rack securely attached to the top of the dealer’s side of the table except for:
Craps; and
Roulette.

section.heading: Roulette — Ball, Table, and Wheel Inspection; Security Procedures.

para.text: A ball used in Roulette shall be:
Made completely of a nonmetallic substance; and
Not less than 12/16 inch nor more than 14/16 inch in diameter.
Roulette shall be played on a table having a Roulette:
Wheel of at least 30 inches in diameter at one end of the table; and
Layout imprinted on the opposite end of the table.
Prior to opening a Roulette table for gaming activity, a floorperson or member of a facility operator’s security department shall:
Inspect the Roulette ball by passing it over a magnet or compass to assure its nonmagnetic quality;
Inspect the Roulette table and Roulette wheel for any magnet or contrivance that would affect the fair operation of the Roulette wheel;
Inspect the Roulette wheel to assure that the wheel is level and rotating freely and evenly; and
Inspect the Roulette wheel to assure that all parts are secure and free from movement.

If a facility operator uses a Roulette wheel that has external movable parts, any adjustments to the movable parts shall be made by a floorperson or a member of the facility operator’s gaming operations department in the presence of a security department member.
All adjustments shall be completed prior to the required inspections under §C of this regulation.

A facility operator may replace any of the movable parts at any time, except that an inspection as required under §C of this regulation shall be completed prior to reopening the Roulette wheel and table for play.
A facility operator shall maintain an inspection log, which shall include:
The date and time of inspection;
The Roulette table number;
Whether an adjustment or replacement was completed;
A description of the adjustment or replacement;
If required, a certification that an inspection was completed; and
The signature and license number of the individual making the adjustment or replacement.
When a Roulette table is not open for play, the Roulette wheel shall be secured by a cover that is placed over the entire wheel and securely locked.
